Dear Mrs. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff pulled youths shoes off, threw youth on the ground,
restrained youth, and twisted youth's neck.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 and
reported they had no further information.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/22/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement and via teams on 4/30/2024. Administrator
reviewed video. Youth A was not successfully restrained by Staff 1
as Youth A dropped his weight resulting in unsuccessful restraints.
Staff 1 took Youth A’s history of AWOLP (Absent Without Legal
Permission) into account based on Youth A’s behavior and
attempted to get Youth A’s backpack due to concerns of AWOLP
and later due to the backpack preventing Staff 1 to complete a
successfully restraint. Staff 3 is new to working shifts as a direct
care worker. Administrator planned to review the video footage
with Staff 3 to use as a coaching tool on ways Staff 3 could have
assisted Staff 1. Staff 2 was on shift during the incident and
addressing a separate incident outside and was not available to
assist Staff 1.
2

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/22/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Youth A reported he got in a fight with Staff 1.
Staff 1 took his shoes off his feet while Youth A sat in a chair.
Youth A described the incident as Staff 1 sat him down in a chair
and slid his shoes off his feet. Youth A started “swinging” at Staff
1. Youth A was unable to recall all the details of the situation as
he “blacked out”. Youth A and Staff 1 ended up outside. Staff 1
took his backpack, Youth A chased Staff 1 to get his backpack.
Youth A tried to punch Staff 1 and Staff 1 ran. Youth A reported
Staff 1 “pinned” him to the ground and Youth A had Staff 1’s
glasses in his hand and Staff 1 “twisted” his head. Youth A broke
Staff 1’s glasses. Youth A laid on the ground on his stomach and
Staff 1 was on top of him. Staff 1 had his hand on the back of
Youth A’s head wrapped around to Youth A’s chin and twisted
Youth A’s neck/head by holding on to Youth A’s chin. Staff 1 had
his knee in Youth A’s back. Staff 1 got off Youth A and said “why
don’t you get up and keep swinging” while Youth A laid on the
ground. Youth A reported Youth B witnessed the incident. Youth
A reported he could not speak after the incident and did not know
why. Staff 4 arrived and took Youth A to the hospital. Youth A
reported both of his ears were bleeding, his throat hurt, and he
had a cut on the inside of his lip as he thought he bit his lip when
he was on the ground. Youth A reported he possibly hit his head
on the ground which caused the blood in his ears. Youth A did not
think Staff 1 was able to restrain him during the incident. Youth A
hit Staff 1 five to six times with a closed fist when Staff 1 took his
shoes off in the house. Youth A reported Staff 1 never hit him.
Staff 1 broke Youth A’s backpack when he tried to take it off as
there was a clip on the backpack that latched under his chin. Staff
1 asked Youth A to take his backpack off several times and Youth
A refused. Staff 1 was able to get Youth A’s backpack off him.
Youth B was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported he
witnessed parts of the incident with Youth A. Youth A had been
outside and was not following Staff 1’s directions to go inside.
Youth A eventually went into the house to his bedroom. Staff 1
asked Youth A to remove his shoes as shoes are not allowed to
be worn in the house. Youth B did not know if Youth A took off his
shoes. Youth B went into the kitchen area and saw Youth A was
mad as Youth A threw things at Staff 1. Staff 1 attempted to get
Youth A to stop throwing items by talking to him. Youth A had a
backpack and Staff 1 thought Youth A was going to try to AWOL.
Staff 1 took Youth A’s backpack from him. Someone, unknown
who, pulled the fire alarm in the house, Youth B went outside.
3

Staff 1 went outside with Youth A’s backpack and Youth A ran
after Staff 1 trying to stab him with sticks. Staff 1 ran with Youth
A’s backpack to get away from Youth A. Youth A caught up to
Staff 1, Staff 1 placed his arms out to use proximity control. Staff
1’s glasses fell off him and Youth A purposely stepped on Staff 1’s
glasses. Youth B did not see Staff 1 do anything to harm Youth A
or put his hands anywhere near Youth A’s head or neck area.
Youth B did not see Staff 1 attempt to restrain Youth A. Youth B
reported Staff 1 used proximity control to keep a distance from
Youth A. Youth B did not see any injuries on Youth A. Youth B
did not see Staff 1 on top of Youth A at anytime. Youth B reported
staff prompt youth to remove their shoes in the house, if youth do
not follow the direction, staff continue to prompt and will remove
the shoes off the youth. Youth B reported staff are not forceful
when removing youth shoes. Youth B reported Youth A laid on the
ground outside the house crying and hyperventilating because he
was overwhelmed from chasing Staff 1 around to try to get his
backpack.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement and
via teams on 5/7/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Staff 1 reported Youth A was upset but didn’t know why. Youth A
asked to go outside and was allowed to however shortly after was
asked to come back inside due to a situation occurring at the
neighboring house. Youth A sat outside in a thorn bush fidgeting
with a rock he had sharpened. Youth A had his water bottle and
backpack. Youth A did not respond to prompts from Staff 1 to go
inside. Staff 1 took Youth A’s water bottle and backpack out of
concern Youth A would attempt to AWOL as Youth A has a
pattern of going AWOL and talked earlier in the day about wanting
to see how long he could survive in the woods. Youth A had been
gifted books on survival and earlier in the day had asked for a
lighter and talked about stealing cars. Staff 1 assessed Youth A’s
behavior and took into account Youth A’s past behaviors and was
concerned. Youth A came in the house. Youth A did not take his
shoes off which is a house rule. Staff 1 asked Youth A his plan to
prepare for bed as Youth A sat in the chair. Youth A did not
respond and stared off with a blank look on his face. Staff 1
asked Youth A if he was ok. Youth A did not respond. Staff 1 was
concerned due to when Youth A is in this type of state, he tends to
escalate fast. Staff 1 waived his hand in front of Youth A’s face in
an attempt get his attention, offered Youth A an extra snack, milk,
or to listen to an audio book per Youth A’s behavioral calming
plan. Youth A did not respond, got up and walked to his bedroom.
Staff 1 followed Youth A to his bedroom as Youth A still had his
4

shoes on and had gotten his backpack back. Youth A entered is
bedroom and sat on his bed and continued to fidget with his sharp
rock. Staff 1 continued to try to talk to Youth A at his bedroom
door, asked for his shoes and offered options for the night. Youth
A did not respond. Staff 1 was concerned that if he did not get
Youth A’s shoes and backpack, Youth A would attempt to AWOL
after night staff arrived. Staff 1 asked Staff 3 to come to the door
and watch as Staff 1 entered Youth A’s bedroom and took Youth
A’s slides (shoes) off his feet. Staff 1 removed Youth A's shoes.
Typical consequences of not following the house rules include
removing toys and books out of youth bedrooms. Staff 1 handed
Youth A’s shoes to Staff 3 and stood in the doorway and used
proximity control as Youth A came to the door and attempted to
leave his bedroom. Staff 1 asked Youth A where he was going,
Youth A did not respond. Youth A dropped to the ground and Staff
1 placed his body in front of Youth A to prevent him from going
outside as Youth A attempted to move toward the exit door. Staff
1 continued verbally de-escalation and offered Youth A options
per Youth A’s behavior calming plan. Staff 1 moved out of the
way and allowed Youth A to leave the bedroom area. Youth A
walked and sat down at the dining room table with his rock and
scratched the table. Staff 1 got the rock gently from Youth A’s
hand and threw the rock in the garbage. Youth A walked toward
the door and Staff 1 used proximity control to prevent Youth A
from going outside due to another situation occurring outside the
front door. Youth A walked over to the table and attempted to
break the table. Youth A walked back to the front door and Staff 1
continued using proximity control. Staff 1 described proximity
control as he used his arm to guide Youth A away from the table
and the door. Staff 1 attempted to get Youth A to go to his
bedroom as it was bedtime. Youth A walked around the kitchen
table into the kitchen area and Staff 1 followed. Youth A grabbed
the sink faucet sanitation system and broke it. Staff 1 gently pried
Youth A’s hand off the faucet. Youth A began swinging to hit Staff
1. Staff 1 blocked the hits and when Youth A went to swing again,
Staff 1 attempted to place Youth A in a benevolent restraint
however Youth A headbutted Staff 1 several times and dropped to
the ground. Staff 1 placed his arm up to block Youth A from
headbutting him by placing his arm between his face and Youth
A’s head. Youth A dropped to the ground in a seated position.
Staff 1 realized he was not able to secure Youth A in the
benevolent restraint due to the backpack. Staff 1 described the
backpack as having four strings for the straps and a latch piece
that clipped under Youth A’s chin/neck area. Staff 1 attempted to
unclip the backpack from under Youth A’s neck area, Youth A bite
Staff 1. Youth A laid on his side on the kitchen floor. Staff 1
5

attempted to take Youth A’s backpack off him. Staff 1 kneeled on
the floor with one knee down, his other knee in the air and
attempted to remove the backpack. Youth A turned to his
stomach to secure the backpack under him, Staff 1 lost his
balance and his knee moved when Youth A rolled to his stomach.
Staff 1 braced himself not to fall and immediately stood up. Staff
1’s knee was on Youth A’s back for a second with no weight on
him. Youth B entered the kitchen and Staff 1 directed Youth B to
leave the kitchen. Youth B remained in the kitchen for a short
time and Staff 1 again directed Youth B to leave the kitchen.
Youth B left the kitchen. Youth A continued to hit and headbutt
Staff 1. Staff 1 got the backpack away from Youth A at which time
Youth A threw a dish at Staff 1. Staff 1’s glasses were knocked off
resulting in Staff 1 having difficulty seeing. The fire alarm started
going off in the house and Youth A attempted to get his backpack
from Staff 1. Staff 1 reported he was not trying to get into a power
struggle with Youth A but was trying to keep him safe. Staff 1
reported Youth A had books and something sharp in the
backpack. Staff 1 told Youth A to exit the house as the fire alarm
was going off. Youth A refused to leave the house and Staff 1
grabbed Youth A’s backpack and used his body weight to pull the
backpack with Youth A holding onto it. Staff 1 had the backpack
and continued out the door of the house and Youth A followed.
Staff 2 took Youth A’s backpack from Staff 1. Youth A attempted
to go toward Staff 2 to get his backpack, Staff 1 stepped in front of
Youth A and Youth A swung at Staff 1. Youth A bit, kicked, and
hit Staff 1. Youth A had a stick and attempted to stab Staff 1 with
the stick. Staff 1 attempted to restrain Youth A and was
unsuccessful as Youth A dropped his weight to the ground. Staff
1 realized Staff 2 set the backpack down as she was addressing
another situation with a separate youth. Youth A saw his
backpack and went toward the backpack, Staff 1 got the backpack
and ran with it. Youth A ran behind Staff 1 with a stick. Staff 1
stopped running and removed the stick from Youth A. Youth A
attempted to bite Staff 1 again, Staff 1 attempted a benevolent
restraint however was unable to secure the restraint due to Youth
A biting. Youth A attempted to punch Staff 1. Staff 1 backed
away from Youth A. Youth A knocked Staff 1’s glasses off him
and stomped on Staff 1’s glasses. Staff 1 attempted to place
Youth A in another restraint at which time Youth A went into a
prone position and Staff 1 released immediately. Youth A laid on
the ground breathing hard. Staff 1 asked Youth A if he was hurt
as Staff 1 was not able to see well without his glasses. Staff 1
noticed Youth A holding his neck. Staff 1 went to check to see if
Youth A was injured and he attempted to bite him and swiped his
hand away. Staff 3 came and stepped in and asked Youth A if he
6

was ok. Youth A did not respond. Staff 4 came and took over.
Staff 1 did not see blood in Youth A’s ear area but later was
informed there was blood. Staff 1 reported the blood could have
been from when Youth A was headbutting him. Staff 1 reported he
never pinned Youth A to the ground, was never on top of Youth A,
never twisted Youth A’s neck or head, and never said anything to
the nature of “why don’t you get up and keep swinging”. Staff 1
reported he did not successfully restrain Youth A during this
incident as Youth A was headbutting, biting, hitting him and due to
the backpack being in the way. Staff 1 reported Youth A was
saying “give me my bag or I will kill you”. Staff 1 never asked
Youth B to assist him during the incident. Staff 1 directed Youth B
to leave the kitchen and living room area when Youth B got near
Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 1 yelled for Staff 3 to assist him
however Staff 3 was with the other youth in the house and Staff 2
was outside addressing another situation. Staff 1 reported he was
aware of Youth A’s behavior calming plan that addresses Youth A
not liking to be physically touched. Staff 1 believed he had rapport
with Youth A as he has been successful in the past in verbally
deescalating Youth A and using his hand to guide Youth A with no
incident which is why he was attempting to use his hands to guide
Youth A while in the house. Staff 1 felt had another staff been
available to assist him, a two-person restraint may have been
successful however there were not any staff available. Staff 3 has
begun picking up shifts at the houses and is newer to working in
the houses as he typically works in other aspects of the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/22/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 2 worked in the house with Staff 1 on the shift
the incident occurred however did not witness the incident due to
being outside with another incident. Staff 2 heard screaming and
Staff 1 asked for her assistance to get Youth A’s backpack off him
when Youth A was outside. Staff 2 assisted Staff 1 and took Youth
A’s backpack off him outside. Staff 2 did not have any other
involvement as Staff 2 was focused on a separate incident. Youth
A did not want to give up his backpack and at the time Staff 2 did
not know why however later learned Youth A had survival books in
his backpack and there was concern he would AWOL. Staff 2 did
not have any concerns with the interactions she witnessed
between Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 2 had not worked with Staff 1
prior to this incident.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/22/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 3 reported Youth A had his backpack and
7

shoes on in the house. Shoes are not allowed to be worn in the
house and Staff 1 prompted Youth A to take his shoes off. Youth
A did not listen. Staff 3 stood in Youth A’s doorway when Staff 1
took Youth A’s shoes off. Youth A had slide on shoes. Youth A
sat on his bed; Staff 1 took Youth A’s shoes. Youth A did not kick
or resist Staff 1 when he removed his shoes. Staff 1 handed Staff
3 the shoes. Youth A exited his bedroom angry with his backpack
on stating he was going to break things and was yelling. Staff 1
attempted to take Youth A’s backpack. Youth A swung at Staff 1,
scratched, and bit him. Youth A made contact and hit Staff 1
when he swung. Staff 1 attempted to place Youth A in a restraint
in the kitchen however was unsuccessful due to Youth A having
his backpack on. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 was unable to
successfully restrain Youth A in the house. Once outside, Youth A
continued to attack Staff 1. Youth A and Staff 1 were in the field
as Youth A would start to run and Staff 1 would run with him to not
allow Youth A to go AWOL. Staff 3 never saw Staff 1 on top of
Youth A or Staff 1 grab Youth A’s head or neck area. Staff 3 saw
Youth A on the ground. Youth A was grabbing at his neck/throat
area and not talking however Staff 1 was not near Youth A. Staff 1
attempted to place Youth A in a restraint once immediately outside
the house however was unsuccessful due to the backpack. There
were other staff around, unable to recall who, however the staff
were addressing other situations with different youth. Staff 4
arrived and assisted with Youth A. Staff 3 reported he had no
concerns with how Staff 1 handled the situation or with Staff 1’s
intervention. Staff 1 attempted to get Youth A’s backpack off and
restrain Youth A. Youth A was screaming and yelling. Staff 3 did
not hear Staff 1 yell or scream at Youth A. Staff 3 did not recall
seeing any blood coming from Youth A’s ears.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Therapist reported Youth A
has expressed he “blacks out” and has trouble recalling details of
events. Therapist had not directly spoken to Youth A regarding
the incident on 4/19/2024 in a one-on-one session however during
group discussion, Youth A verbalized he was upset about staff
taking his backpack. Therapist was informed there was food and
a large zip tie in Youth A’s backpack that was taken by staff.
Youth A is protective of his belongings.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 4/19/2024 in Hainley house was viewed on
4/22/2024. Youth A was sitting in a chair in the living room with his
shoes on and backpack on his back. Staff 1 stood off to the side
and appeared (due to no sound on the video) to be talking Youth
8

A. Youth A went to his bedroom, Staff 1 followed. Staff 3 stood in
Youth A’s doorway and Staff 1 went in the bedroom and came out
with Youth A’s shoes and handed them to Staff 3. Staff 1 stood in
the bedroom doorway with his arm across the door. Youth A
walked up to Staff 1 and walked into his arm to leave the
bedroom. Youth A dropped to the floor to crawl under Staff 1’s
arm. Staff 1 pivoted his body to stand in front of Youth A and the
wall. Youth A stood up and walked away from his bedroom door,
Staff 1 followed. Youth A had his backpack on and water bottle.
Staff 1 walked in front of Youth A as they walked to the living
room. Staff 1 walked to the front door and positioned himself in
front of the door. Youth A walked to the locked door where shoes
are kept, pushed on the locked door, and walked toward the front
door. Staff 1 walked toward Youth A, Youth A turned and walked
to the dining room table. Youth A sat down and was scratching the
table with a rock in his hand. Staff 1 removed the rock from Youth
A’s hand. Youth A stood up and walked around the table. Staff 1
remained in close proximity. Youth A held the table edge and
attempted to push down on the table to break it. Staff 1 stood next
to Youth A and Youth A moved from the table. Staff 1 followed
Youth A toward the hall to the bedrooms. Youth A turned around,
Staff 1 used his body to stay in front of Youth A. Staff 1 took a
hold of Youth A’s wrist, Youth A attempted to move past Staff 1,
Staff 1 shifted his body in front of Youth A. Staff 1’s arm was in
one of the strings on Youth A’s backpack. Youth A walked toward
the kitchen; Staff 1 followed holding the string of the backpack.
Youth A grabbed the faucet in the kitchen, Staff 1 removed the
faucet from Youth A’s hand. Staff 1 had his left arm around the
back of Youth A’s waist as he removed the faucet from Youth A’s
hand. Youth A headbutted Staff 1 twice and on the third headbutt,
Staff 1 placed his hand/arm in between Youth A’s head and his
face. Youth A dropped to the ground, and it appeared Staff 1’s
hand followed on the back of Youth A’s head as Youth A dropped
to a seated position on the floor. Staff 1 removed the water bottle
from Youth A’s hands. Youth A stood up and swung to punch Staff
1. Staff 1 stepped back, Youth A grabbed the water bottle off the
counter and attempted to hit Staff 1 with it. Staff 1 went in toward
Youth A. Youth A turned and dropped to the ground and was
laying on his side. Staff 1 held on to Youth A trying to release the
latch of the backpack under Youth A’s chin. Youth A was turning
on the floor with his legs. Staff 1 let go of Youth A’s latch as
Youth A tried to bite him. Youth A stood up and went toward Staff
1. Staff 1 attempted a benevolent restraint, but Youth A dropped
to the floor. Youth A laid on his side, Staff 1 had one knee on the
floor and the other in the air as he went to the ground with Youth
A. Youth A continued to swing his head back toward Staff 1 and
9

rolled to a kneeling position with his hands on the ground. Staff 1
remained with one knee on the ground and his other knee
transitioned with Youth A as Youth A rolled to his stomach. Staff 1
immediately stood up and Youth A stood up. Staff 1 attempted a
benevolent restraint. Youth A dropped to the ground in a seated
position, Staff 1 released. Youth A crawled over to grab the water
bottle on the floor, Staff 1 took the water bottle and threw it behind
him. Youth A continued to crawl on the floor and Staff 1 followed
attempting to remove Youth A’s backpack. Youth A held on to the
backpack strings. Staff 1 was unable to remove the backpack.
Youth A hit Staff 1 in the legs, got up and swung at Staff 1 and
threw a dish. Youth B came into the kitchen and pushed Youth A.
Youth A went to grab the toaster off the counter and Staff 1
attempted a benevolent restraint. Youth A dropped to a seated
position and headbutted Staff 1. Staff 1 released. Youth A got up
and hit Staff 1 several times. Youth B sat on the counter and got
down and was next to Youth A and Staff 1. Youth B stepped back
away. Youth A continued to hit and kick Staff 1. Youth A laid on
the ground with his backpack string wrapped around his left knee.
Staff 1 attempted to remove the backpack but was unsuccessful.
Staff 1 looked toward Youth B. Youth B left the kitchen. Staff 1
continued attempting to remove the backpack. Youth A got up and
walked out of the kitchen, Staff 1 followed. Youth A walked into
the living room, headed toward the front door. Staff 1 stepped in
front of Youth A and placed his hands on Youth A’s upper
shoulders. Youth A turned and pushed his body weight against
Staff 1. Youth A dropped to a seated position. Staff 1 removed his
hands from Youth A’s upper arms. Youth A got up, moved toward
the hall to the bedroom area as Staff 1 followed. Youth A turned
toward Staff 1 and Staff 1 had his hands out on Youth A’s
shoulder area. Youth A dropped to the ground and hit Staff 1.
Staff 1 blocked the hits from Youth A. Youth A got up and
continued to hit Staff 1. Staff 1 attempted a benevolent restraint.
Youth B came in and appeared to be trying to remove one of the
backpack strings. Staff 3 entered the living room from the
bedroom hallway. Youth B stepped away from Staff 1 and Youth
A. Youth A continued resisting Staff 1. Staff 3 walked past Staff 1
and Youth A. The fire alarm in the house went off as there were
flashing lights. Youth A laid on the floor facing up. Staff 1 stood
over Youth A. Staff 3 walked by Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 1
continued to try to get the strings of the backpack from Youth A.
Youth A held the backpack. Youth A rolled on to his stomach
holding the backpack. Staff 1 got a hold of the backpack and held
the backpack as he walked toward the front door. Youth A held
the backpack strings and laid on the floor moving with Staff 1 as
Staff 1 pulled the backpack. Youth A stood up once at the door
10

while still holding the backpack strings when Youth A and Staff 1
exited the house. There was no further video.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Villate Incident Report for Youth A dated 4/19/2024
at 8pm completed by Staff 1. The incident report was
consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
• Eagle Village Basic House Rules: Shoes, boots, coats,
hats, gloves, and zip-up sweatshirts are to be kept in the
mudroom. They are not allowed upstairs or in bedrooms.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Potential AWOLP (Absent Without Legal
Permission) Risks: When youth give indications of possibly
running away, staff must confront the youth regarding the
information and should place their shoes/slippers and
clothes in a secured area as an added deterrent. Staff are
to be in close proximity to the youth until the youth is no
longer an AWOLP risk.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures AWOLP and out of Bounds Procedures: A
youth is considered AWOLP if there is clear evidence that
they left campus or if they are out of staffs’ eyesight for a
maximum of 20 minutes in which searches have failed to
locate the youth. A youth is considered Out-of-Bounds if
they’re still on the campus. There is nothing in the
procedure that states staff are to prevent youth from going
AWOLP by blocking doors of the house.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Behavior and Calming Plans: Behavior and
calming plans are more than just managing the youths’
physical behavior; it involves the entire treatment process to
the end of helping the youth manage their own behavior in a
socially healthy and respectful manner, while using a
trauma-informed approach. Behavior and calming plans
involve the entire team and everyone working together to
help the youth achieve their goals.
• Behavior and Calming Plan for Youth A dated 12/4/2023:
This plan was created to assist staff when deescalating
Youth A if he becomes frustrated or escalated. Known
triggers for Youth A include being order around,
transitioning from one activity to a less enjoyable one, not
understanding expectations, being touched when he does
not initiate it. Activities that help calm Youth A include
11

snacks, being outside, building forts, fishing, video games,
and reading. Staff will utilize Aegis verbal de-escalation
techniques when Youth A is escalated and may use an
Aegis restraint if there are signs of imminent safety.
• Behavior and Calming Plan for Youth A dated 4/23/2024:
This plan is consistent with Behavior and Calming Plan for
Youth A dated 12/4/2023 and additionally includes Youth A
has been having behavioral concerns surrounding “survival
living”. Youth A is not to have survival living books, zip-ties,
paracord, and/or be sharpening sticks to make weapons. If
items are found, they should be confiscated, and the
supervisor/on call supervisor should be notified.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 received discipline on
1/9/2023 for an unrelated matter and on 11/8/2023 for
physically intervening with a youth and not following Aegis
techniques. Staff 1 received Aegis verbal de-escalation
training 1/3/2024 and Aegis restraint training 8/9/2023.

Rule Code Behavior management
Title

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility does not have a behavior management policy.
Investigation Interviews:
Administrator was interviewed via teams on 4/30/2024.
Administrator reported she did not believe the facility had any
policy/procedure to address behavior management regarding
specific behaviors and consequence for youth not following rules
and how staff were to intervene as outlined in licensing rule
400.4157.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/22/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Youth A reported Staff 1 asked him several times
to remove his shoes and backpack and Youth A refused to follow
Staff 1’s directions. Youth A did not know what the consequences
were at the facility for not following staff directions.
Youth B was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported a house
rule is youth cannot wear shoes in the house. Youth B reported
staff prompt youth to remove their shoes in the house, if youth do
not follow the direction, staff continue to prompt and will remove
the shoes off the youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/23/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement and
via teams on 5/7/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Staff 1 reported one of the house rules is youth are not to wear
shoes in the house. Staff 1 made the decision to remove Youth
A’s shoes as Youth A was not following the rule. Staff 1 did not
know what the facilities guidelines are to address when youth
wear shoes and refuse to follow directions. Staff 1 reported
typical consequences of not following the house rules include
removing toys and books out of youth bedrooms.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as the facility does not have
a behavioral management policy. The facility has not supplied
13

youth and staff with an outline to address expected behaviors and
consequence to the behaviors using a positive intervention
strategy.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered as follows:
• Implement a behavior management policy per the licensing
rules to address expected staff interventions to youth
behaviors including when youth do not follow house rules,
are potential AWOLP, and refuse to follow staff direction
and provide to the facilities assigned licensing consultant.
• Provide education to staff on AWOLP, licensing rules
related to preventing a youth from AWOLP, and
expectations of staff when a youth is or concerns of going
AWOLP.
Conclusion Violation Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
